title.rendered: Faster Shopify product pages with one line of code

content.rendered:
“A picture is worth a thousand words“.

Henrik Ibsen’s words (no pun intended) remain true up to this day, especially for merchants running e-commerce businesses. Without a decent number of quality images it’s simply very difficult to convey how good one’s product is.

However, adding a vast array of crystal clear, high quality images comes with a particular downfall: even if all images are properly resized and compressed, your store will still have a decent amount of speed sacrificed.

Thankfully not everything is lost and there is one skillful, simple strategy to go around this issue: lazyload the description images.

Understanding what may be making your product page slower

Whenever you add images to your description in the Product admin area the images tag <img /> are not accessible in the code since it’s rendered via .liquid:

{{ product.description }}

Because of that we are supposedly limited to customize it. So, how can we lazyload those description images if we don’t have access to the code itself?

Ok, so how do I address this issue?

Simple, we can use Shopify’s native replace function to replace all <img tags with <img loading=”lazy”.

The step by step process looks like this:

  1. Go to Online Store > Themes > Actions > Edit Code;
  2. Find product-template.liquid file;
  3. Press CTRL +F (or CMD + F on Mac) and search for the code below:
    {{ product.description
  4. You’ll find one or more pieces of the code above in your product-template.liquid file. Delete the entire line and replace all of them with the following:
    {{ product.description | replace: “<img”, “<img loading=’lazy'” }}
  5. Save.

For reference, this is how it looked on my client’s theme.

Before:



After:

Conclusion

Native lazy loading through data attribute is new, so bear in mind that it may not work on every single device (yet). Here you can double check all the browsers it currently works on.

However, with this same technique you’re able to lazyload via Javascript as well if you wish. With the replace function you could easily add a data-attribute and then wire it up with something like vanilla-lazyload, which is super lightweight. It’s possible to even extend this to videos and iframes.
